sections.heading: What is C++?
paragraphs: C++ is a cross-platform language that can be used to create high-performance applications.
C++ was developed by Bjarne Stroustrup, as an extension to the C language.
C++ gives programmers a high level of control over system resources and memory.
The language was updated 5 major times in 2011, 2014, 2017, 2020, and 2023 to C++11, C++14, C++17, C++20, and C++23.

sections.heading: Why Use C++
paragraphs: C++ is one of the world's most popular programming languages.
C++ can be found in today's operating systems, Graphical User Interfaces, and embedded systems.
C++ is an object-oriented programming language which gives a clear structure to programs and allows code to be reused, lowering development costs.
C++ is portable and can be used to develop applications that can be adapted to multiple platforms.
C++ is fun and easy to learn!
As C++ is close to C, C# and Java, it makes it easy for programmers to switch to C++ or vice versa.

sections.heading: Difference between C and C++
paragraphs: C++ was developed as an extension of C, and both languages have almost the same syntax.
The main difference between C and C++ is that C++ supports classes and objects, while C does not.

sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: When you are finished with this tutorial, you will be able to write C++ programs and create real-life examples.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.

sections.heading: Install C++
paragraphs: If you want to run C++ on your own computer, you need two things:
list: A text editor, like Notepad, to write C++ code
A compiler, like GCC, to translate the C++ code into a language that the computer will understand
sections.note: There are many text editors and compilers to choose from. In the next steps, we will show you how to use an IDE that includes both.

sections.heading: Install C++ IDE
paragraphs: An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit AND compile the code.
Popular IDE's include Code::Blocks, Eclipse, and Visual Studio. These are all free, and they can be used to both edit and debug C++ code.
sections.note: Web-based IDE's can work as well, but functionality is limited.

sections.heading: Code::Blocks
paragraphs: We will use Code::Blocks in our tutorial, which we believe is a good place to start.
Download the mingw-setup.exe file, which will install the text editor with a compiler.

sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: Line 1: #include <iostream> is a header file library that lets us work with input and output objects, such as cout (used in line 5). Header files add functionality to C++ programs.
Line 2: using namespace std means that we can use names for objects and variables from the standard library.
Don't worry if you don't understand how #include <iostream> and using namespace std works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program.
Line 3: A blank line. C++ ignores white space. But we use it to make the code more readable.
Line 4: Another thing that always appear in a C++ program is int main(). This is called a function. Any code inside its curly brackets {} will be executed.
Line 5: cout (pronounced "see-out") is an object used together with the insertion operator (<<) to output/print text. In our example, it will output "Hello World!".
notes: C++ is case-sensitive: "cout" and "Cout" has different meaning.
Every C++ statement ends with a semicolon ;.
The body of int main() could also been written as: int main () { cout << "Hello World! "; return 0; }
The compiler ignores white spaces. However, multiple lines makes the code more readable.

sections.heading: Return Statement
paragraphs: Line 6: return 0; ends the main function.
Line 7: Do not forget to add the closing curly bracket } to actually end the main function.

sections.heading: C++ Comments
paragraphs: Comments can be used to explain C++ code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.
Comments can be singled-lined or multi-lined.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by the compiler (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code:
// This is a comment
cout << "Hello World!";

sections.heading: Single-line Comment at End of Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:

example.title: Example
example.code: cout << "Hello World!"; // This is a comment

sections.heading: C++ Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by the compiler:

sections.heading: Single or multi-line comments?
paragraphs: It is up to you which you want to use.
Normally, we use // for short comments, and /* */ for longer.

sections.heading: C++ Variables
paragraphs: Variables are containers for storing data values.
In C++, there are different types of variables (defined with different keywords), for example:
list: int - stores integers (whole numbers), without decimals, such as 123 or -123
double - stores floating point numbers, with decimals, such as 19.99 or -19.99
char - stores single characters, such as 'a' or 'B'. Char values are surrounded by single quotes
string - stores text, such as "Hello World". String values are surrounded by double quotes
bool - stores values with two states: true or false

sections.heading: C++ User Input
paragraphs: You have already learned that cout is used to output (print) values. Now we will use cin to get user input.
cin is a predefined variable that reads data from the keyboard with the extraction operator (>>).
In the following example, the user can input a number, which is stored in the variable x. Then we print the value of x:

example.title: Example
example.code:
int x;
cout << "Type a number: "; // Type a number and press enter
cin >> x; // Get user input from the keyboard
cout << "Your number is: " << x; // Display the input value

list: cout is pronounced "see-out". Used for output, and uses the insertion operator (<<)
cin is pronounced "see-in". Used for input, and uses the extraction operator (>>)

sections.heading: C++ Booleans
paragraphs: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:
YES / NO
ON / OFF
TRUE / FALSE
For this, C++ has a bool data type, which can take the values true (1) or false (0).

paragraphs: A boolean variable is declared with the bool keyword and can take the values true or false:

paragraphs: If you prefer to print true and false as words instead of 1 and 0, you can use the boolalpha manipulator:

sections.note: boolalpha is not a data type. It is an I/O manipulator - a setting that changes how cout displays boolean values.

sections.heading: Resetting Back With noboolalpha
paragraphs: If you want to go back to the default behavior (printing 1 and 0), you can use noboolalpha:

example.title: Example
example.code:
bool isCodingFun = true;

cout << boolalpha;   // print as true/false

cout << noboolalpha; // reset to 1/0
cout << isCodingFun << "\n";  // Outputs 1

sections.note: You can switch between them using boolalpha and noboolalpha.

sections.heading: Tip
paragraphs: Tip: You can read more about cout and its manipulators in our C++ cout object reference.
In real programs, boolean values are usually the result of comparing values or variables.

Use else to specify a block of code to be executed, if the same condition is false
Use else if to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false
Use switch to specify many alternative blocks of code to be executed

cpp_data_structures_and_stl.title: C++ Data Structures and STL

overview.definition: Data structures are ways to store and organize data efficiently.
overview.purpose: They allow programs to manage large amounts of data effectively.
overview.stl_meaning: STL stands for Standard Template Library.

stl_description: STL is a powerful C++ library that provides ready-made data structures and algorithms.
It helps write efficient, reusable, and optimized code.
Choosing the right data structure and algorithm improves performance.

core_components_of_stl.containers: Store and manage data (e.g., vector, list, map).
core_components_of_stl.iterators: Provide a way to access and traverse container elements.
core_components_of_stl.algorithms: Perform operations like sorting, searching, and modifying data.

relationship_explained: Algorithms work on data through iterators

common_stl_data_structures.name: Vector
common_stl_data_structures.description: Dynamic array that allows fast index-based access.
common_stl_data_structures.best_use: When fast access and dynamic resizing are needed

common_stl_data_structures.name: List
common_stl_data_structures.description: Doubly linked list allowing insertion/removal at both ends.

common_stl_data_structures.name: Deque
common_stl_data_structures.description: Double-ended queue allowing insertion/removal at both ends.

common_stl_data_structures.name: Set
common_stl_data_structures.description: Stores unique elements in sorted order.

common_stl_data_structures.name: Map
common_stl_data_structures.description: Stores key-value pairs with unique keys.

exam_key_points: Choosing the right structure improves performance

common_exam_question.question: What is the purpose of data structures in C++?

cpp_vector.title: C++ Vector (Dynamic Array)
overview: A vector is a resizable array that can grow or shrink dynamically.
Stores multiple elements of the same data type in contiguous memory.
Provides fast random access using index numbers.
characteristics: Optimized for insertion/removal at the end

sections.heading: Create a Vector
sections.description: Define a vector by specifying the element type.
notes: The data type of a vector cannot be changed after declaration.

sections.heading: Access Elements
sections.description: Vectors support index-based access.
notes: at() throws an exception if index is out of range.

sections.heading: Modify Elements
sections.description: Change elements using index access.

sections.heading: Add Elements
sections.description: Vectors grow dynamically by adding elements at the end.
notes: Insertion at the end is efficient.
Frequent insertions in the middle are costly.

sections.heading: Remove Elements
sections.description: Remove elements from the end of the vector.

sections.heading: Loop Through a Vector
sections.description: Vectors support index-based and range-based loops.

examples.code: for (int i = 0; i < cars.size(); i++) { cout << cars[i]; }

vector_vs_array: Vector: dynamic size, safer access, rich member functions
Array: fixed size, no built-in size or bounds checking
vector_vs_deque: Vector: fast random access, optimized for back insertion
Deque: allows fast insertion/removal at both ends

when_to_use: When you need fast random access
When the size may change dynamically
When most insertions/removals happen at the end

cpp_list.title: C++ List (Doubly Linked List)
overview: A list stores multiple elements of the same type and can grow or shrink dynamically.
It allows fast insertion and removal at both the beginning and the end.
Unlike vectors, lists do NOT support random (index-based) access.
characteristics: Fast insertion/removal at front and back

sections.heading: Create a List
sections.description: Define a list by specifying the element type.
notes: The data type of a list cannot be changed after declaration.

sections.heading: Access Elements
sections.description: Lists do not support index access. You can only access the first or last element.

sections.heading: Modify Elements
sections.description: You can modify the first or last element directly.

sections.heading: Add Elements
sections.description: Insert elements at either end of the list.

sections.heading: Remove Elements
sections.description: Remove elements from either end of the list.

sections.heading: Loop Through a List
sections.description: Lists must be iterated using range-based loops or iterators.
notes: Traditional index-based loops do NOT work with lists.

list_vs_vector: List: fast insert/remove at both ends, no random access
Vector: fast random access, optimized for insertion/removal at the end

when_to_use: Frequent insertions and deletions in the middle or at both ends
When random access is not required
Implementing queues, deques, or custom data pipelines

cpp_stack.title: C++ Stack (LIFO Data Structure)
overview: A stack stores elements using LIFO order (Last In, First Out).
Elements are added to and removed from the top of the stack.
Only the top element is accessible.

sections.heading: Create a Stack
sections.description: Define a stack by specifying the element type.
notes: Stack elements cannot be initialized at declaration time.
The data type of a stack cannot be changed after declaration.

sections.heading: Add Elements
sections.description: Elements are added to the top of the stack using push().

sections.heading: Access Elements
sections.description: Only the top element can be accessed.

sections.heading: Modify the Top Element
sections.description: You can change the value of the top element directly.

sections.heading: Remove Elements
sections.description: Elements are removed from the top using pop().

cpp_stack.comparison_note: Unlike a queue (FIFO), a stack follows LIFO where the most recently added element is accessed first.
when_to_use: Undo/redo functionality
Function call management (call stack)
Expression evaluation
Backtracking algorithms
Reversing data

cpp_queue.title: C++ Queue (FIFO Data Structure)
overview: A queue stores elements using FIFO order (First In, First Out).
Elements are added at the back and removed from the front.
Random access by index is not allowed.

sections.heading: Create a Queue
sections.description: Define a queue by specifying the element type.
notes: Queue elements cannot be initialized at declaration time.
The data type of a queue cannot be changed after declaration.

sections.heading: Add Elements
sections.description: Elements are added to the back of the queue using push().

sections.heading: Access Elements
sections.description: Only the front and back elements can be accessed.

sections.heading: Modify Front and Back Elements
sections.description: You can change the values of the front or back elements directly.

sections.heading: Remove Elements
sections.description: Elements are removed from the front using pop().

cpp_queue.comparison_note: Unlike a deque, a queue only allows insertion at the back and removal from the front.
when_to_use: When processing tasks in order of arrival
When FIFO behavior is required
When random access is unnecessary
When modeling real-world queues (tasks, requests, buffers)

cpp_deque.title: C++ Deque (Double-Ended Queue)
overview: A deque allows insertion and removal of elements at both the front and the back.
Elements can be accessed by index, unlike queues.
It combines features of vectors and queues.
characteristics: Insertion and removal at both ends

sections.heading: Create a Deque
sections.description: Define a deque by specifying the element type.

sections.heading: Access Elements
sections.description: Access elements using index, front/back, or at().

sections.heading: Modify Elements
sections.description: Change element values using index or at().

sections.heading: Loop Through a Deque
sections.description: Iterate using index-based loops or range-based for loops.

examples.code: for (int i = 0; i < cars.size(); i++) { cout << cars[i]; }

cpp_deque.comparison_note: Unlike a queue, a deque allows insertion and removal from both ends.
when_to_use: When you need fast insertion/removal at both ends
When indexed access is required
When a queue is too restrictive
When flexibility is more important than strict ordering rules

cpp_sets.title: C++ Sets
overview: A set stores unique elements.
Elements are automatically sorted in ascending order by default.
Duplicate values are ignored.
Elements cannot be accessed by index.
characteristics: Access is done via iteration or lookup, not indexing

sections.heading: Create a Set
sections.description: Create a set by specifying the type of elements it will store.

sections.heading: Automatic Sorting
sections.description: Elements are sorted automatically when inserted.

sections.heading: Descending Order
sections.description: Use the greater<type> functor to sort in descending order.

example.code: set<int, greater<int>> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 2, 5, 9};

sections.heading: Unique Elements
sections.description: Duplicate values are ignored automatically.

example.code: set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "BMW", "Mazda"};
cars.insert("Tesla");

sections.heading: Loop Through a Set
sections.description: Iterate using a range-based for loop or iterators.

example.code: for (string car : cars) { cout << car << "\n"; }

when_to_use: When all elements must be unique
When sorted data is required
When fast lookup, insertion, and deletion are needed
When element order matters but indexing does not

cpp_maps.title: C++ Maps
overview: A map stores elements as key/value pairs.
Each key is unique and used to access its corresponding value.
Elements are automatically sorted in ascending order by key.

sections.heading: Create a Map
sections.description: To create a map, specify the key type and value type using angle brackets.

sections.heading: Access Map Elements
description: Map elements cannot be accessed using index numbers.
They are accessed using their keys.
notes: Using operator[] creates a new element if the key does not exist.
The at() function throws an exception if the key does not exist.

sections.heading: Change Values
sections.description: Values associated with a key can be modified after creation.

sections.heading: Add Elements
sections.description: New key/value pairs can be added dynamically.

sections.heading: Map Characteristics
points: Elements are automatically sorted by key
Access time is logarithmic (balanced tree structure)
Ideal for fast lookup by key

sections.heading: When to Use Maps
use_cases: Any situation where data is identified by a unique key

cpp_iterators.title: C++ Iterators
overview: Iterators are used to access and loop through elements of data structures such as vectors, lists, and sets.
They work like pointers by referring to a position in a container rather than returning a value.
The term iterator comes from the concept of iterating, which means looping.

sections.heading: Basic Iterator Example
sections.description: This example shows how to loop through a vector using an iterator.
explanation: A vector of strings is created to store car names.
An iterator (it) is declared for the vector.
cars.begin() points to the first element in the vector.
cars.end() points to one position after the last element.
*it dereferences the iterator to access the value it points to.

sections.heading: Iterator Type Matching
notes: The iterator type must match the container type.
For example, vector<string>::iterator is required for a vector<string>.

sections.heading: begin() and end() Functions
description: begin() and end() belong to containers, not to iterators themselves.
They are used together with iterators to traverse a container.
details: begin() returns an iterator to the first element.
end() returns an iterator to one position past the last element.

sections.heading: Using end()
sections.description: end() does not point to a real element, but to one position after the last element.

example.code: it = cars.end() - 1;

sections.heading: Why Iterators Are Called "Pointers"
content: Iterators behave like pointers because they refer to a specific position in a container.
They allow access and modification of elements without copying values.
This makes them efficient and flexible for use with algorithms.

cpp_algorithms.title: C++ Algorithms
overview: Algorithms are used to sort, search, and manipulate data stored in data structures like vectors and lists.
C++ provides a rich set of algorithms through the <algorithm> library.
Most algorithms work with iterators such as begin(), end(), rbegin(), and rend().

sections.heading: Sorting Algorithms
sections.description: Sorting rearranges elements in a data structure into a specific order.
notes: sort() sorts in ascending order by default
Reverse iterators can be used for descending order

sections.heading: What Is a Namespace?
content: A namespace is used to group related code under a name.
It helps avoid naming conflicts when programs grow larger or when using multiple libraries.
You can think of a namespace like a folder that separates identifiers with the same name.

sections.heading: Why Use Namespaces?
content: Avoid name conflicts in large projects
Organize code into logical groups
Separate your code from external libraries

sections.heading: Basic Namespace Example
content: This example defines a variable inside a custom namespace and accesses it using the scope resolution operator (::).

sections.heading: The using namespace Keyword
content: The using keyword allows access to namespace members without writing the full namespace name.
This can make code shorter but may cause name conflicts in large programs.

sections.heading: The std Namespace
content: Standard C++ features like cout, cin, and endl belong to the std namespace.
Without using std, you must prefix these items with std::.

sections.heading: With using namespace std
Best Practices
content: Using namespace std is fine for small programs and learning.
In large projects, prefer std:: to avoid conflicts.
Use namespaces thoughtfully to keep code clean and maintainable.

sections.heading: Why Build Projects?
content: Understand how real programs are structured
Practice combining concepts like functions, loops, and file handling
Improve debugging and problem-solving skills
Prepare for interviews and practical exercises
sections.tip: Start small and gradually add more features.

This example shows how to add two predefined integer values and print the result.

cpp_generate_random_numbers.title: C++ How To Generate Random Numbers

sections.heading: Random Numbers in C++
content: C++ provides functions to generate random numbers using the standard library.
The rand() function is used to generate pseudo-random numbers.

sections.heading: Using rand()
content: The rand() function is found in the <cstdlib> library.
It generates a random integer each time it is called.

sections.heading: Random Numbers in a Range
content: To limit the random number to a specific range, you can use the modulo operator (%).
This example generates a random number between 0 and 100.

sections.heading: Different Results Each Run
content: By default, rand() generates the same sequence of numbers each time the program runs.
To generate different results, use srand() with the current time as the seed.

sections.heading: Using srand() with time()
content: The srand() function sets the starting point for generating random numbers.
The time() function from the <ctime> library is commonly used as the seed value.

sections.heading: C++ Reference
content: This section contains reference documentation for the C++ programming language.
It provides an overview of C++ keywords and commonly used standard libraries.

sections.heading: Keywords
content: C++ keywords are reserved words that form the core syntax of the language.
They cannot be used as identifiers such as variable or function names.

sections.heading: Standard Libraries
content: <iostream>: Provides input and output stream objects.
<fstream>: Provides file stream classes for file handling.
<cmath>: Contains mathematical functions.
<string>: Provides string handling and manipulation.
<cstring>: Provides functions for C-style string and memory handling.
<ctime>: Provides date and time functions.
<vector>: Provides the vector container.
<algorithm>: Provides algorithms for searching, sorting, and modifying data.

sections.heading: Purpose of the Reference
content: The C++ reference serves as a quick lookup for syntax, keywords, and library functionality.
It is useful for both beginners and experienced developers who need concise technical details.

sections.heading: C++ Keywords
content: Keywords are reserved words in C++ that have special meanings and cannot be used as identifiers.
They form the core syntax of the C++ language.

sections.heading: Logical and Bitwise Keywords
content: and, or, not: Alternative keywords for logical operators (&&, ||, !).
and_eq, or_eq, not_eq: Alternative assignment and comparison operators.
bitand, bitor, xor, compl: Alternative keywords for bitwise operators.

sections.heading: Data Types
content: bool: Stores true or false values.
char: Stores a single character.
int, short, long: Store integer values with different sizes.
float, double: Store fractional numbers.
signed, unsigned: Control whether values can be negative.

sections.heading: Control Flow
content: if, else: Conditional statements.
switch, case, default: Multi-branch selection statements.
for, while, do: Looping constructs.
break, continue: Control loop execution.
goto: Jumps to a labeled statement (generally discouraged).

sections.heading: Functions and Exceptions
content: return: Returns a value from a function.
void: Indicates no return value or unspecified type.
try, catch, throw: Exception handling keywords.

sections.heading: Classes and Objects
content: class, struct: Define user-defined types.
public, private, protected: Access specifiers.
this: Pointer to the current object.
friend: Grants access to private and protected members.
virtual: Enables dynamic dispatch in inheritance.

sections.heading: Memory Management
content: new: Allocates dynamic memory.
delete: Frees dynamically allocated memory.
sizeof: Returns the size of a type or variable.

sections.heading: Templates and Namespaces
content: template: Declares template classes or functions.
typename, typedef: Define or alias types.
namespace: Declares a namespace.
using: Brings names from a namespace into scope.

sections.heading: Miscellaneous
content: auto: Automatically deduces variable type.
const: Declares constants or read-only methods.
static: Gives static storage duration or class-level scope.
true, false: Boolean literals.

sections.heading: iostream Library
content: The <iostream> library provides standard input and output stream objects in C++.
It allows programs to read input from the keyboard and write output to the console or other streams.

sections.heading: Purpose of <iostream>
content: Used for standard input, output, and error handling.
Forms the foundation of console-based interaction in C++ programs.

sections.heading: Standard Input and Output Objects
content: cin: Reads input from the standard input (keyboard by default).
cout: Writes output to the standard output (console by default).

sections.heading: Error and Logging Streams
content: cerr: Outputs error messages (unbuffered).
clog: Outputs logging information (buffered).

sections.heading: Wide Character Streams
content: wcin: Wide-character version of cin.
wcout: Wide-character version of cout.
wcerr: Wide-character version of cerr.
wclog: Wide-character version of clog.

sections.heading: Usage Notes
content: iostream streams use the insertion (<<) and extraction (>>) operators.
They can be combined with other stream libraries such as <fstream> for file I/O.

sections.heading: fstream Library
content: The <fstream> library provides classes for reading from and writing to files in C++.
It enables file input and output operations using stream-based syntax.

sections.heading: Purpose of <fstream>
content: Used to handle file operations such as reading, writing, and appending data.
Works with files as data streams, similar to console input and output.

sections.heading: Core File Stream Classes
content: ifstream: Used to read data from files.
ofstream: Used to write data to files.
fstream: Used for both reading and writing files.

sections.heading: Low-Level File Handling
content: filebuf: A low-level buffer class used internally by file stream classes.
It manages the actual file data transfer between memory and storage.

sections.heading: Common Use Cases
content: Reading text or binary files.
Writing program output to files.
Appending data to existing files.

sections.heading: File Handling Notes
content: Files should always be properly opened before use and closed after operations.
Error handling is important to ensure file accessibility and integrity.

sections.heading: cmath Library
content: The <cmath> library provides a wide range of mathematical functions in C++.
It supports trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential, rounding, and special mathematical operations.

sections.heading: Purpose of <cmath>
content: Used to perform advanced mathematical calculations.
Commonly applied in scientific, engineering, and numerical applications.

sections.heading: Basic Math Functions
content: abs(): Returns the absolute value.
fabs(): Returns the absolute value of a floating-point number.
pow(): Raises a number to a power.
sqrt(): Returns the square root.
cbrt(): Returns the cube root.

sections.heading: Rounding and Remainder
content: ceil(): Rounds up to the nearest integer.
floor(): Rounds down to the nearest integer.
round(): Rounds to the nearest integer.
trunc(): Removes the fractional part.
fmod(): Returns the remainder of division.

sections.heading: Trigonometric Functions
content: sin(), cos(), tan(): Trigonometric functions using radians.
asin(), acos(), atan(): Inverse trigonometric functions.
atan2(): Computes angle from x and y coordinates.

sections.heading: Hyperbolic Functions
content: sinh(), cosh(), tanh(): Hyperbolic functions.
asinh(), acosh(), atanh(): Inverse hyperbolic functions.

sections.heading: Logarithmic and Exponential Functions
content: log(): Natural logarithm.
log10(): Base-10 logarithm.
log2(): Base-2 logarithm.
exp(): Exponential function.
exp2(): Power of 2 exponent.

sections.heading: Advanced and Special Functions
content: hypot(): Calculates sqrt(x² + y²).
gamma(), tgamma(): Gamma function values.
erf(), erfc(): Error functions.
nan(): Generates a NaN value.
copysign(): Copies sign from one number to another.

sections.heading: string Library
content: The <string> library provides the std::string class for handling text in C++.
It offers safer and more convenient string handling compared to C-style strings.

sections.heading: Purpose of <string>
content: Used to store and manipulate sequences of characters.
Automatically manages memory and provides many built-in utility functions.

sections.heading: Element Access
content: at(): Returns the character at a specified position with bounds checking.
operator[]: Returns the character at a given index.
front(): Accesses the first character.
back(): Accesses the last character.
c_str(): Returns a C-style null-terminated string.
data(): Returns a pointer to the internal character array.

sections.heading: Capacity and Size
content: size(): Returns the number of characters in the string.
length(): Alias of size().
empty(): Checks whether the string is empty.
max_size(): Returns the maximum possible size of the string.
resize(): Changes the size of the string.

sections.heading: Modifiers
content: append(): Adds characters or another string to the end.
push_back(): Adds a single character to the end.
pop_back(): Removes the last character.
insert(): Inserts characters at a specified position.
erase(): Removes characters from the string.
replace(): Replaces part of the string with new content.
clear(): Removes all characters.
swap(): Exchanges contents with another string.

sections.heading: Search and Compare
content: find(): Finds the first occurrence of a character or substring.
rfind(): Finds the last occurrence of a character or substring.
compare(): Compares the string with another string.
substr(): Returns a substring starting at a given position.

sections.heading: Iterators
content: begin(): Returns an iterator to the first character.
end(): Returns an iterator past the last character.

sections.heading: cstring Library
content: The <cstring> library provides functions for working with arrays and C-style strings.
C-style strings are arrays of characters terminated by a null character ('\0').

sections.heading: Purpose of <cstring>
content: Used for low-level string and memory manipulation.
Commonly applied when working with character arrays instead of std::string.

sections.heading: Memory Manipulation Functions
content: memchr(): Finds the first occurrence of a value in a block of memory.
memcmp(): Compares two blocks of memory.
memcpy(): Copies memory from one location to another.
memmove(): Copies memory safely when blocks overlap.
memset(): Sets all bytes in a block of memory to a specific value.

sections.heading: String Concatenation and Copying
content: strcat(): Appends one C-style string to another.
strncat(): Appends a specified number of characters.
strcpy(): Copies a C-style string.
strncpy(): Copies a specified number of characters.

sections.heading: String Comparison and Search
content: strcmp(): Compares two C-style strings.
strncmp(): Compares a specified number of characters.
strcoll(): Compares strings using locale settings.
strchr(): Finds the first occurrence of a character.
strrchr(): Finds the last occurrence of a character.
strstr(): Finds a substring within a string.

sections.heading: String Analysis and Utilities
content: strlen(): Returns the length of a C-style string.
strspn(): Finds length up to first non-matching character.
strcspn(): Finds length up to first matching character.
strpbrk(): Finds first matching character from a set.
strtok(): Splits a string into tokens.
strerror(): Returns a description of an error code.
strxfrm(): Transforms strings using locale rules.

sections.heading: ctime Library
content: The <ctime> library provides functions for working with date and time in C++.
It allows programs to measure time, manipulate timestamps, and format date and time values.

sections.heading: Purpose of <ctime>
content: Used to retrieve the current system time.
Helps calculate time differences and convert between time formats.

sections.heading: Time Retrieval Functions
content: time(): Returns the current time as a timestamp.
clock(): Returns the processor time used by the program.

sections.heading: Time Conversion Functions
content: ctime(): Converts a timestamp into a readable string.
asctime(): Converts a tm structure into a readable string.
gmtime(): Converts a timestamp to UTC time.
localtime(): Converts a timestamp to local time.

sections.heading: Time Calculation
content: difftime(): Calculates the difference between two timestamps.
mktime(): Converts a tm structure back into a timestamp.

sections.heading: Time Formatting
content: strftime(): Formats date and time values into a string using custom formatting options.

sections.heading: Vector Library
content: The <vector> library provides a dynamic array implementation in C++.
Vectors can automatically resize and provide many built-in functions for managing elements.

sections.heading: Purpose of <vector>
content: Vectors store elements contiguously in memory.
They allow fast access to elements and efficient insertion and removal at the end.

sections.heading: Element Access
content: at(): Returns the element at a specified position with bounds checking.
front(): Returns the first element of the vector.
back(): Returns the last element of the vector.
data(): Returns a pointer to the underlying array.

sections.heading: Capacity Functions
content: size(): Returns the number of elements in the vector.
capacity(): Returns the amount of allocated storage.
max_size(): Returns the maximum number of elements the vector can hold.
empty(): Checks whether the vector is empty.
reserve(): Requests memory allocation.
shrink_to_fit(): Reduces capacity to fit the current size.

sections.heading: Modifiers
content: assign(): Assigns new values to the vector.
push_back(): Adds an element to the end.
pop_back(): Removes the last element.
insert(): Inserts elements at a specified position.
erase(): Removes elements from the vector.
clear(): Removes all elements.
swap(): Swaps contents with another vector.
resize(): Changes the number of elements.

sections.heading: Iterators
content: begin(): Returns an iterator to the first element.
end(): Returns an iterator to one past the last element.
rbegin(): Returns a reverse iterator to the last element.
rend(): Returns a reverse iterator to before the first element.

sections.heading: Algorithm Library
content: The <algorithm> library provides functions to perform operations on ranges of data.
These functions work with containers such as arrays, vectors, and other STL data structures.

sections.heading: Purpose of <algorithm>
content: It allows modification, searching, sorting, and analysis of data ranges.
Most functions operate on iterators rather than containers directly.

sections.heading: Searching Algorithms
content: adjacent_find(): Finds consecutive elements with the same value.
binary_search(): Checks if a value exists in a sorted range.
find(): Finds the first occurrence of a value.
find_if(): Finds the first element matching a condition.
find_if_not(): Finds the first element that does not match a condition.
search(): Finds a sequence of values within a range.

sections.heading: Counting and Checking
content: count(): Counts how many times a value appears.
count_if(): Counts elements matching a condition.
all_of(): Checks if all elements satisfy a condition.
any_of(): Checks if at least one element satisfies a condition.
none_of(): Checks if no elements satisfy a condition.

sections.heading: Sorting and Ordering
content: sort(): Sorts elements in ascending order.
is_sorted(): Checks if a range is sorted.
is_sorted_until(): Finds where sorting stops.
lower_bound(): Finds the first element not less than a value.
upper_bound(): Finds the first element greater than a value.

sections.heading: Replacing and Modifying
content: replace(): Replaces matching values in a range.
replace_if(): Replaces values that match a condition.
fill(): Assigns a value to all elements in a range.
for_each(): Applies a function to each element.

sections.heading: Copying and Merging
content: copy(): Copies elements to another range.
merge(): Merges two sorted ranges.
reverse_copy(): Copies elements in reverse order.

sections.heading: Reordering and Swapping
content: reverse(): Reverses the order of elements.
random_shuffle(): Randomly rearranges elements.
swap(): Swaps two values.
swap_ranges(): Swaps elements between two ranges.

sections.heading: Min and Max
content: min_element(): Finds the smallest element in a range.
max_element(): Finds the largest element in a range.
